Award.AwardTitle: Optimizing Energy Management in Microgrids with Datacenters: An Integrated Approach

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Microgrids are localized grids that have become an integral component of future smart grids. Meanwhile, datacenters have been expanding enormously to support the exploding digital economy worldwide, emerging as significant energy consumers that are commonly co-located with a diverse set of non-datacenter loads in microgrids. Nonetheless, prior research on datacenter energy management, although encouraging, has traditionally viewed datacenters as isolated stand-alone facilities and rarely considered their physical interconnection with other loads. On the other hand, the rich literature on microgrid energy management has primarily focused on non-datacenter loads (e.g., thermostatically controlled loads), while treating energy-intensive datacenters as miscellaneous loads and ignoring their unique global-routing capabilities. This lack of integration and coordination between datacenter and non-datacenter loads poses a series of challenges to microgrid management, such as high peak demand, waste of on-site renewables, and even potential threats to the stability of main grids.

This project seeks to address the challenges and optimize microgrid energy management for minimizing the energy cost and facilitating demand responses to better protect the main grid. Towards this end, this project takes a transformative shift from the current view that treats datacenter and non-datacenter loads separately, to an integrated approach that holistically coordinates both datacenter and non-datacenter loads in microgrids. Specifically, this project investigates two complementary research thrusts. First, when the microgrid operator can directly schedule the loads, this project investigates novel control algorithms to holistically manage both datacenter and non-datacenter loads, while taking into account datacenters spatial-routing and heterogeneous communications capabilities. Second, when the loads are managed by self-interested entities, this project studies market mechanisms to coordinate both datacenter and non-datacenter loads for microgrid-level efficiency.

This project advances the existing research on microgrid energy management by transforming datacenters' role in microgrids from miscellaneous loads into a valuable asset with high scheduling flexibilities. It can catalyze a shift in the way that microgrids evolve, bearing great economic, environmental and societal impacts. This project will also incorporate the research into existing courses and provide abundant opportunities to nurture and attract students, especially those from under-represented groups, to engage in research careers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Microgrids are localized power networks that have become an integral component of future smart grids. Meanwhile, datacenters, especially geo-distributed edge datacenters, have been emerging as significant energy consumers in microgrids. This grant supported our research to develop an integrated approach to optimizing energy management and demand response for both datacenter loads and non-datacenter loads, achieving system-level integration and coordination in future energy systems.

Focusing on mixed-use buildings with significant computer and datacenter loads as an important class of microgrids, this project developed novel algorithms based on model predictive control to exploit the scheduling flexibility of both datacenter loads and HVAC (heating, ventilating, and air conditioning) loads in a collaborative manner. The algorithms effectively lower peak demand and reduce energy cost for mixed-use buildings, while satisfying various requirements on room temperature, ventilation, and datacenter workload deadlines. The algorithms are also integrated with state-of-the-art reinforcement learning to optimize energy management in a set of geo-distributed mixed-use buildings by utilizing the unique spatial routing flexibility of datacenter loads. The learning-based algorithms can autonomously learn an effective energy management policy for each mixed-use building, while different buildings collaborate with each other to achieve system-level coordination and reduce the overall energy cost. Importantly, the algorithms can quickly adapt to environment changes and yield effective energy management policies for co-scheduling datacenter and HVAC loads in mixed-use buildings. The algorithms designed in this project represent one of the early solutions that leverage online control and learning to jointly manage datacenter loads and non-datacenter loads in mixed-use building microgrids.  

In the presence of self-interested entities, demand response has been a proven, powerful tool for achieving system-level efficiency and coordination. Thus, an important focus of this project was to understand how market approaches can help reshape the energy demands of different entities and lead to coordinated behaviors for system efficiency in a mixed-use microgrid with datacenter loads. For example, this project tapped into the time-varying unused power capacity in a microgrid serving different self-interested users that have different workload priorities, and developed a novel market approach to coordinate different users’ energy demand for maximizing the overall power capacity utilization. Furthermore, when making demand response decisions, microgrid operators often face an uncertain environment resulting from several factors such as intermittent renewables and dynamic energy demands of users. Such uncertainties may result in arbitrary worst-case outcomes if not properly addressed. As motivated by the need of robust demand response in microgrids, this project formalized a theoretically-rigorous framework where the agent needs to make robust decisions with imperfect contextual information and an unknown reward function. Under the framework, several algorithms were developed to achieve different goals, such as the system’s worst-case robustness and average performance. Importantly, theoretical bounds were derived to provide a rigorous characterization of the algorithms’ performance. While the algorithms take inspiration from demand response in microgrids, they are also general enough and suitable for a variety of other applications such as online resource management in cloud computing.

Additionally, this project advances the way that different energy loads currently interact with each other by enabling more secure and reliable communications, which is crucial for an integrated approach to optimal energy management and demand responses in mixed-use microgrids

The research supported by this grant has the potential for broader impact in other areas through the development of advanced control and learning tools for optimally managing complex networked systems.  For example, users’ workloads are important side information for dynamic resource management in cloud computing, but only predicted workloads are available in practice subject to prediction errors. Going beyond microgrids, the algorithms in this project provide new perspectives and integrated approaches for optimizing real-world systems, such as cloud computing, in the presence of uncertainties. Finally, as part of the grant, the PI has supported in part multiple PhD students, integrated the research into the existing curriculum at UCR, and attracted students from under-represented groups to engage in STEM careers.
